51964.meaning_1: the Great Householder Sutta; a discourse addressed to a great householder
51964.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
mahāsālasutta is the 14th sutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya 7 (Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta). It is a discourse addressed to a great householder (mahāsāla), explaining the Dhamma in the context of household life. The compound is a kammadhāraya where mahāsāla (great householder) qualifies the noun sutta (discourse).

55921.meaning_1: wearing a rough cloak; dressed in a shabby overgarment
55921.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term lūkhapāvuraṇa describes someone who wears a rough or shabby cloak. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14, it characterizes a well-to-do brahmin who has adopted an outward appearance of simplicity or austerity, wearing coarse garments despite his social status. This reflects the ascetic aesthetic common in renunciant traditions, where rough clothing symbolizes detachment from luxury.
55921.sutta_1: atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo lūkho lūkhapāvuraṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
55921.example_1: Then a certain well-to-do brahmin, shabby, wearing a shabby cloak, went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

55920.meaning_1: wearing a rough cloak; dressed in a shabby overgarment
55920.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word lūkhapāpuraṇa appears in SN7.14 describing a Brahmin who approaches the Buddha wearing rough or shabby clothing, symbolizing ascetic practice. The variant lūkhapāvuraṇo in the text is a scribal variation. The term combines lūkha "rough, coarse" with pāpuraṇa "cloak, covering", forming a kammadhāraya compound meaning "one who wears a rough cloak". This reflects the ascetic ideal of simplicity in early Buddhist literature.
55920.example_1: sāvatthinidānaṃ. atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇamahāsālo lūkho lūkhapāvuraṇo  [lūkhapāpuraṇo] yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi. sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.

61623.meaning_1: at the request; at the behest (of)
61623.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN7.14, the gerund saṃpuccha is used with the instrumental case dārehi (wives) to indicate that the sons left the house at the request or behest of their wives. The construction dārehi saṃpuccha literally means "asked by the wives" or "at the asking of the wives", conveying the idea of acting upon someone's request or instruction.
61623.example_1: idha me, bho gotama, cattāro puttā. te maṃ dārehi saṃpuccha gharā nikkhāmentīti. tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imā gāthāyo pariyāpuṇitvā sabhāyaṃ mahājanakāye sannipatite puttesu ca sannisinnesu bhāsassu –

36790.meaning_1: drives out; expels; ejects; evacuates; excretes
36790.phonetic:
īk > ikkh
k > kh (Kacc 20, 27)
a > ā
36790.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:1.6, "te maṃ dārehi sampuccha gharā nikkhāmentī"ti", nikkhāmeti is used in the sense of "expels" or "drives out" — specifically, the speaker is saying "at their wives' bidding they expelled me from my house." This reflects the causative nature of the verb, causing someone to go out from a place. The dual case government (+acc & +abl) is evident: the person being expelled (accusative) and the place they are expelled from (ablative).
36790.sutta_1: te maṃ dārehi sampuccha gharā nikkhāmentī”ti.
36790.example_1: At their wives’ bidding they expelled me from my house.”

49572.meaning_1: wished for the well-being; desired the prosperity (of)
49572.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form bhavamicchi is an aorist compound verb meaning "wished for the well-being" or "desired the prosperity" of someone. It occurs in SN 7.14:2.2 where it describes a benevolent wish directed toward others. The compound is formed from bhavaṃ (well-being, prosperity) and icchi (wish, desire), with the sandhi change ṃi > mi. This reflects a compassionate intention rather than a selfish desire.

9429.grammar: adj, from prp of na atthi
9429.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:3.1, "asantā kira maṃ jammā" translates to "It turns out they're wicked, those nasty men." Here, asanta is used in the plural nominative form (asantā) to describe people who are morally bad or unvirtuous. The literal meaning "not existing" has evolved metaphorically to mean "wicked" or "bad" in ethical context, reflecting the Pāḷi worldview where virtue is associated with true existence and goodness, while vice is seen as a form of non-existence or spiritual death.
9429.example_1: It turns out they’re wicked, those nasty men,

46649.grammar: ind, adv, comp, instr sg of puttarūpa
46649.meaning_1: in the form of sons; with the appearance of sons
46649.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In SN 7.14:3.3, "rakkhasā puttarūpena" describes demons or malevolent beings who appear in the guise of sons, suggesting a deceptive or threatening form. The instrumental case ending -ena indicates manner or means, thus "in the form of sons" or "with the appearance of sons." This reflects a common Pāḷi literary device where supernatural beings take familiar human forms to mislead or harm.
46649.example_1: They’re monsters in the shape of sons,

66340.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
vayogata means "grown old" or "reached old age". The contextual sentence from SN 7.14 shows someone being cast aside due to old age: "te jahanti vayogataṃ" = "they abandon him as he has grown old". The compound is formed from vayo (age) + gata (gone), literally "gone to age".
66340.example_1: throwing me out as I’ve grown old.

24738.meaning_1: gets a foothold; finds a footing
24738.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The verb gādhamedhati means "to get a foothold" or "to find a footing", used literally in the sense of finding stable ground, especially in deep or difficult conditions. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:6.2, "gambhīre gādhamedhati" means "in deep waters it finds a footing", suggesting stability or security even in challenging circumstances. The compound is formed from gādhaṃ (a foothold, foundation) and edhati (to thrive, grow, gain strength), with the phonetic change ṃe > me due to sandhi.
24738.example_1: in deep waters it finds a footing.

23579.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
khalitvā is the absolutive (gerund) form of khalati "to stumble, trip". In the contextual sentence from SN7.14:6.4, it expresses the idea of "having stumbled" and is followed by patitiṭṭhati "I stand firm", conveying the moral that even when one stumbles in life, one can regain stability. The absolutive here indicates a prior action that sets the stage for the main verb.
23579.example_1: when I stumble, I stand firm again.’”

41802.meaning_1: stands firm again; recovers; regains footing
41802.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The verb patitiṭṭhati means "to stand back" or "to stand firm again" after stumbling or falling. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.14:6.4, "khalitvā patitiṭṭhatī'ti", it conveys the sense of recovering one's footing or composure after a misstep. The prefix pati- intensifies the meaning of the root √ṭhā "to stand", giving the sense of standing firmly or resolutely.
41802.example_1: when I stumble, I stand firm again.’”

38766.meaning_1: having led; having taken; having guided
38766.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN7.14:13.1, netvā means "having led" or "having taken" and refers to the action of the brahmin's sons leading their father back home. The absolutive netvā expresses a prior action to the main verb, indicating the sequence: first they led him home, then they bathed and clothed him.
38766.sutta_1: atha kho naṃ brāhmaṇamahāsālaṃ puttā gharaṃ netvā nhāpetvā paccekaṃ dussayugena acchādesuṃ.
38766.example_1: Then the brahmin’s sons led him back home, bathed him, and each clothed him with a fine pair of garments.

52272.meaning_1: the discourse on gaining advantage; the sutta about gaining benefit
52272.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.15, a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches about gaining spiritual advantage through proper conduct and understanding. The compound means "discourse on gaining advantage" where māna means "gain" or "advantage", attha means "benefit" or "purpose", dhā is a verbal element meaning "holding" or "establishing", and sutta means "discourse" or "thread".

36533.meaning_1: does not speak; does not say anything
36533.construction:
na + ā + lapa + ti
na + ālapati
36533.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This negative form expresses deliberate silence in response to another's silence, as seen in SN 7.15 where the speaker vows not to speak if Gotama does not speak first. The construction clearly shows the negation of ālapati through the addition of na-, maintaining the same transitive +accusative syntax.
36533.sutta_1: no ce maṃ samaṇo gotamo ālapissati, ahampi nālapissāmī”ti.
36533.example_1: But if he doesn’t speak, neither will I.”

36534.meaning_1: did not speak; did not say anything
36534.construction:
na + ā + lapa + i
na + ālapi
36534.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the negative aorist form of ālapati, meaning "did not speak" or "did not address". In the context of SN 7.15:1.11, it describes the Buddha's deliberate silence towards someone, indicating refusal to engage in conversation or address the person.
36534.example_1: But the Buddha didn’t speak to him.

39341.meaning_1: the Paccanīka Sutta; a discourse on the antidote
39341.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The Paccanīka Sutta (SN 7.16) is a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches the brahmin Jānussoṇi about the "antidote" (paccanīka) to defilements. The term paccanīka means "antidote, counteraction, opposite" and refers to the Dhamma practice that counteracts unwholesome states. The sutta emphasizes mindfulness and the cultivation of wholesome qualities as the remedy for mental impurities.

49228.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
bhaṇati 2 is a specialized sense of the verb bhaṇati meaning "to preach, recite, or chant sacred texts." In the contextual sentence from SN 7.16, the Buddha instructs a monk to "preach the Dhamma" (bhaṇa samaṇadhamman), using the causative sense of reciting or proclaiming religious teachings. This distinguishes it from bhaṇati 1, which has the general meaning "to speak, say, tell." The specialized meaning is confirmed by related forms like bhaññamāna 2 "being chanted; being preached" and bhāṇaka "reciter; chanter of scriptures."

15372.meaning_1: with a defiled mind; mentally corrupt
15372.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word upakkiliṭṭhacitta means "with a defiled mind" or "mentally corrupt". It is a compound formed from upakkiliṭṭha (defiled, tainted) and citta (mind, consciousness). In the contextual sentence from SN 7.16:2.3, it describes someone whose mind is tainted or morally impure. The compound functions as an adjective describing a mental state characterized by defilement or moral corruption.

62495.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word sārambhabahula describes a state of being full of aggression or hostility. In the context of SN 7.16:2.4, it modifies a noun (likely a person or being) that is characterized by a belligerent or quarrelsome nature. The component sārambha refers to strife, conflict, or aggression, while bahula means "full of" or "abounding in". This compound is used to emphasize a strong tendency towards conflict or hostility.

35902.meaning_1: Sutta about the young carpenter; discourse addressed to a young carpenter
35902.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.17, a discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches a young carpenter (navakammika) about the nature of suffering and the path to liberation. The term "navakammika" means "young carpenter" (nava = new/young, kammika = worker/carpenter), and "sutta" refers to the discourse itself.

35901.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is a compound name referring to a Brahmin known as "Bhāradvāja the Builder" or "Bhāradvāja associated with new work/construction." The first element "navakammika" means "related to new work or building" (nava = new, kamma = work), and "bhāradvāja" is a common Brahmin family name. The contextual sentence from SN7.17 shows he was having building work done in a jungle thicket, confirming the meaning "Builder Bhāradvāja."
35901.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo tasmiṃ vanasaṇḍe kammantaṃ kārāpeti.
35901.example_1: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Builder was having some building work done in that jungle thicket.

62566.meaning_1: foot of a sal tree; base of a sal tree
62566.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.17, the Buddha is described as sitting at the foot of a sal tree (sālarukkhamūle), which is a locative singular form. This compound refers to the base or root area of a sal tree (Shorea robusta), a tree of great significance in Buddhist literature, often associated with important events such as the Buddha's birth and death. The construction shows a chaṭṭhī tappurisa (genitive) compound, literally meaning "root of the sal tree."
62566.sutta_1: addasā kho navakammikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ aññatarasmiṃ sālarukkhamūle nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
62566.example_1: He saw the Buddha sitting down cross-legged at the root of a certain sal tree, his body set straight, and mindfulness established in his presence.

20469.meaning_1: there is something to be done (by); there is something to do
20469.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
karaṇīyamatthi is an impersonal compound verb meaning "there is something to be done" or "there is something to do". It is used in the negative in the text: "na me vanasmiṃ karaṇīyamatthi" — "There's nothing I need do in the jungle". The compound is formed from karaṇīyaṃ "to be done" + atthi "there is", with sandhi change ṃa > ma. It takes the instrumental case to indicate the agent by whom the action should be done.
20469.example_1: “There’s nothing I need do in the jungle;

19389.meaning_1: the wood-carrier discourse; the sutta about the wood carrier
19389.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the "Wood-Carrier Sutta" (SN 7.18), a discourse in the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The title literally means "wood-carrying discourse", referring to a bhikkhu who earns his living by carrying wood. The sutta deals with themes of contentment, simplicity, and the proper way of life for a bhikkhu, contrasting the humble wood-carrier with the lofty spiritual path.

24466.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
gambhīrarūpa is used in the sense of "deep" to describe the jungle (vana) as profound or unfathomable in its form, evoking a sense of mystery and danger. The compound combines gambhīra "deep" with rūpa "form, appearance" in a kammadhāraya (descriptive) compound, literally meaning "deep in form" and figuratively "profound, awesome in appearance".
24466.example_1: “Deep in the jungle so full of terrors,

67371.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The gerund vigāhiya appears in SN 7.18 describing one who has plunged into or deeply penetrated the empty, desolate wilderness. The form vigāhiya is an alternative to vigayha, both expressing the action of diving or plunging into something, often used metaphorically for deep engagement or immersion.
67371.example_1: you’ve plunged into the empty, desolate wilderness.

66221.meaning_1: resorted to the forest; living in the wood
66221.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The form vanavassita in the text is the nominative singular feminine agreeing with muni (which can be used as a feminine noun in poetic contexts) or more likely a typo/variant for vanavassito (masc. nom. sg.). The compound means "one who has resorted to the forest" or "forest-dweller", composed of vana "forest" and āvassita "resorted to, dwelling in". It describes a sage who has gone to live in the wilderness, a common theme in early Buddhist literature symbolizing renunciation and meditation.
66221.example_1: a lonely sage resorts to the wilderness.

1114.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word accherarūpa appears in SN 7.18:3.3 as accherarūpaṃ paṭibhāti maṃ idaṃ, meaning "This strikes me as an amazing thing." The compound is formed from acchera (marvellous, wonderful) and rūpa (form, appearance), literally meaning "marvellous form" or "wonderful in nature." It is used to express astonishment at something extraordinary or miraculous.
1114.example_1: This strikes me as an amazing thing,

56035.meaning_1: fellowship with the ruler of the world; company of god almighty
56035.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word lokādhipatisahabyatā means "fellowship with the ruler of the world" or "company of God almighty." It is a feminine compound noun formed from lokādhipati ("ruler of the world, God") and sahabyatā ("companionship, fellowship"). In the context of SN 7.18:4.1, it refers to the desire to be reborn in the company of the divine ruler, indicating a spiritual or devotional aspiration.
56035.example_1: I suppose you wish to be reborn in the company

67545.meaning_1: resorting to uninhabited forest; living in desolate jungle
67545.compound_construction: vijanaṃ araññaṃ assito ti, vijanaṃ + araññaṃ + āśrita
67545.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term vijanamaraññamassita describes a person who has taken up residence in a remote, uninhabited forest. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.18, it refers to a contemplative or ascetic who lives in solitude in the wilderness, likely for meditation or spiritual practice. The word is a compound formed from vijanaṃ (uninhabited, desolate), araññaṃ (forest, wilderness), and āśrita (resorted to, dependent on). The phonetic change ṃa > ma is a common sandhi feature in Pāḷi compounds.
67545.example_1: Is that why you resort to the desolate wilderness,

57952.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.18:5.2, "anekadhātūsu puthū sadāsitā", the word sadāsita describes a state of being always attached or ever dependent upon the many and various realms. It conveys a sense of continuous clinging or attachment to diverse states of existence, indicating a lack of liberation from samsaric conditions.
57952.example_1: to the many and various realms—

1614.meaning_1: born from the root of ignorance; sprung from the source of not knowing
1614.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This compound describes mental formations (pajappitā) that arise dependent on ignorance (aññāṇa) as their foundational cause. The contextual sentence from SN 7.18 illustrates how yearnings or cravings originate from this root of unknowing, emphasizing the Buddhist teaching that ignorance is the primary condition for the arising of suffering.
1614.example_1: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—

48748.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word byantikata means "ended; eliminated; stopped" and is used in SN 7.18:5.4 to express complete eradication "down to the root". It is a kammadhāraya compound formed from byanta ("ended, finished") and kata ("made, done"). The v > b phonetic change is regular in Pāḷi. The contextual sentence shows it used in the sense of completely eliminating defilements or problems at their root cause.
48748.example_1: I’ve eliminated them all down to the root.

69302.meaning_1: having clear vision; seeing clearly; (comm) having omniscient knowledge (of)
69302.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the context of SN 7.18:6.2, "sabbesu dhammesu visuddhadassano" means "amongst all things, my vision is clear." This describes a state of purified, unobstructed insight or understanding, often associated with the Buddha's omniscient knowledge. The compound is a kammadhāraya where "visuddha" (pure, clear) qualifies "dassana" (vision, seeing), literally meaning "clear-seeing" or "pure vision."
69302.example_1: amongst all things, my vision is clear.

52237.meaning_1: the Mother-Follower Discourse; a discourse about one who follows or serves their mother
52237.compound_construction: mātāya ahaṃ posako ti suttaṃ yatra tat
52237.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.19, the "Mother-Follower Discourse" in the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The title refers to a discourse about a person (posaka) who follows or serves their mother (mātā). The compound is a kammadhāraya where "mātā" (mother) qualifies "posaka" (follower, servant), and together they modify "sutta" (discourse). The text likely deals with themes of filial duty, gratitude, and proper conduct toward one's mother.

52234.meaning_1: supporting one's mother; providing for one's mother
52234.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word mātuposaka refers to someone who supports or provides for their mother. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.19, it describes a brahmin who cares for his mother, indicating filial piety. The compound is formed from mātar (mother) and posaka (supporting, nourishing), functioning as an adjective describing a person's character or role.
52234.sutta_1: atha kho mātuposako brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
52234.example_1: Then a brahmin who provided for his mother went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

49861.meaning_1: the Bhikkhaka Sutta; a discourse on begging
49861.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term bhikkhakasutta refers to a specific sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN7.20) within the Brāhmaṇasaṃyutta. The compound is formed from bhikkhaka ("begging" or "a beggar") and suttā ("discourse" or "sutta"). It is a kammadhāraya compound where the first member qualifies the second, indicating a discourse concerning begging or addressed to beggars. The Sanskrit equivalent shows the same components: bhikṣaka (beggar) + sūkta/sūtra (discourse).

56961.meaning_1: the Saṅgārava Sutta; the discourse addressed to Saṅgārava the brahmin
56961.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is SN 7.21, the discourse in the Saṃyutta Nikāya where the Buddha teaches the brahmin Saṅgārava about the true nature of purification, emphasizing that it is not achieved through ritual bathing in rivers but through ethical conduct and mental purification. The title literally means "the sutta (discourse) concerning Saṅgārava."

14896.meaning_1: purified by water; relating to water purification
14896.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term udakasuddhika refers to one who is purified by water or who practices purification through water. In the context of SN 7.21, it describes a brahmin who is devoted to ritual purification by immersing himself in water at dawn and dusk, reflecting a pre-Buddhist ascetic practice.
14896.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena saṅgāravo nāma brāhmaṇo sāvatthiyaṃ paṭivasati udakasuddhiko, udakena parisuddhiṃ pacceti, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
14896.example_1: Now at that time there was a brahmin named Saṅgārava staying in Sāvatthī. He practiced purification by water, believing in purification by water. He lived committed to the practice of immersing himself in water at dawn and dusk.

14894.meaning_1: water purification; ritual purification by water
14894.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.21, the Buddha questions a brahmin about his practice of "udakasuddhi", which refers to ritual purification by water. This term denotes the act or practice of purifying oneself through water, a common ritual practice in ancient Indian religions. The compound consists of "udaka" (water) and "suddhi" (purity/purification), formed as a kammadhāraya compound where the first member qualifies the second.
14894.sutta_1: “kiṃ pana tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, atthavasaṃ sampassamāno udakasuddhiko, udakasuddhiṃ paccesi, sāyaṃ pātaṃ udakorohanānuyogamanuyutto viharasī”ti?
14894.example_1: “But brahmin, for what reason do you practice purification by water?”

38923.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
In the contextual sentence from SN 7.21, the word nhāna refers to ritual bathing as a means of purification. The speaker explains that they wash away bad deeds committed during the day by bathing at dusk, and those committed at night by bathing at dawn. This reflects the ancient Indian belief in the purificatory power of water, where physical bathing symbolizes moral and spiritual cleansing. The term is neuter gender and functions as a verbal noun (action noun) derived from the root √nhā meaning "to bathe".
38923.sutta_1: “idha me, bho gotama, yaṃ divā pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti, taṃ sāyaṃ nhānena pavāhemi, yaṃ rattiṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ hoti taṃ pātaṃ nhānena pavāhemi.
38923.example_1: “It’s because, worthy Gotama, whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the day I wash off by bathing at dusk; and whatever bad deeds I’ve done during the night, I wash off by bathing at dawn.

23977.meaning_1: the Khomadussa Sutta; the discourse about the dust and dirt
23977.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This is the name of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 7.22), known as the Khomadussa Sutta. The title is a kammadhāraya compound meaning "dust-dirt discourse" or "the discourse about dust and dirt", likely referring to the metaphorical use of dust and dirt to illustrate spiritual defilements.

23975.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
This entry represents the toponymic use of khomadussa, referring to a village in the Sakyan territory where the Buddha stayed. The word is etymologically derived from "khoma" (flax) and "dussa" (cloth), literally meaning "flax cloth", but in this context it functions as a place name. The compound type is kammadhāraya, indicating that the village is characterized by or associated with flax cloth production. The contextual sentence from SN 7.22 confirms this as a geographical location within the Sakyan realm.
23975.sutta_1: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakkesu viharati khomadussaṃ nāmaṃ sakyānaṃ nigamo.
23975.example_1: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Khomadussa.

23976.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The word khomadussaka is a taddhita derivative formed by adding the suffix -ka to khomadussa, indicating belonging or origin. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.22, it refers to the brahmins and householders who are from the village of Khomadussa. The meaning "from Khomadussa; living in Khomadussa" is clearly supported by the context where people from this place are gathered in the council hall.
23976.sutta_1: tena kho pana samayena khomadussakā brāhmaṇagahapatikā sabhāyaṃ sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
23976.example_1: Now at that time the brahmins and householders of Khomadussa were gathered in the council hall for some business, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

59088.meaning_1: council rules; protocols of the assembly
59088.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term sabhādhamma refers to the established rules or protocols governing conduct within a council or assembly. In the contextual sentence from SN 7.22, the speaker questions whether certain ascetics understand these council rules, implying they are acting improperly or without proper knowledge of communal discipline. The compound is formed from sabhā ("assembly, council") and dhamma ("law, rule, principle"), functioning as a kammadhāraya (determinative) compound where sabhā qualifies dhamma.
59088.sutta_1: “ke ca muṇḍakā samaṇakā, ke ca sabhādhammaṃ jānissantī”ti?
59088.example_1: “Who are these shavelings, these fake ascetics? Don’t they understand the council rules?”

36764.meaning_1: the sutta that has gone forth; the discourse that has been delivered
36764.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The term nikkhantasuttaṃ in SN8.1 refers to a specific discourse in the Vaṅgīsasaṃyutta. The compound means "the sutta that has gone forth" or "the discourse that has been delivered," with nikkhanta meaning "gone forth, departed, delivered" and sutta meaning "discourse, thread." This appears to be the title of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya collection.

31836.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
daditvā is the absolutive form of dadāti "to give, offer, donate". In the contextual sentence from SN 7.12:3.3, it functions as a temporal clause meaning "when the donors have given" or "after giving", indicating the action of giving that precedes the main verb. The form is irregular, built from the reduplicated present stem dadā + itvā, rather than the expected datvā from the root √dā + tvā.
31836.example_1: Again and again, when the donors have given,

39682.comment:
openrouter: kwaipilot/kat-coder-pro:free
The contextual sentence aññāṇamūlappabhavā pajappitā, "the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing," illustrates pajappita as a neuter abstract noun meaning "yearning" or "desire" that arises from ignorance. It refers to the mental formations or cravings that stem from delusion, a key concept in Buddhist teachings on the origin of suffering.
39682.example_1: the yearnings sprung from the root of unknowing—
